title: From spiders to spin: celebrity judges will make ideal brand ambassadors
text:
I recently heard a QC complain that he would never consider becoming a judge nowadays, not just because the pay is rubbish but because the job simply doesn’t carry the status it once did.

In the old days, a judge travelling to hear a case would be greeted at the station by local officials, ferried to an official lodging in a nice car and dressed up in robes that signified the standing of the law they represented. The job often meant taking a pay cut, but the ceremony and the perks promoted the idea that it was a noble vocation.

Nowadays, judges haul their suitcases to the local Travelodge and show up to court without so much as a handshake greeting. Quite right, you might say.
